channel.title: Documents That Changed the World
channel.description: A look at documents that have had a profound effect on the world. Telling the stories of these information objects, their genesis, contexts, impacts, and fates also tells the story of human society and its never ending evolution.
channel.itunes:subtitle: Revealing the power and importance of information
channel.itunes:author: Joe Janes
channel.itunes:summary: A look at documents that have made a difference in the world. Joe Janes, of the University of Washington Information School, tells the stories of these important information objects, how and why they were created, and the impacts they've had. These documents also tell the story of human society. and its never ending evolution. Look for our Podcast in the iTunes Store

item.title: Electoral College Documents, 2020
item.itunes:subtitle: Papers, signatures, seals, ceremonies, rules that produce documents to let hundreds speak for millions in having their say in the most important decision they make

item.title: World's Fair Time Capsule, 1938
item.itunes:subtitle: The best known example of an attempt to help the future to understand the present when it's the past, even 5000 years on

item.title: Articles of Impeachment, 1868
item.itunes:subtitle: The extraordinary ordinariness of articles of impeachment, then and now, and the lessons to be learned, over and over again

item.title: Code of Hammurabi, c1754 BCE
item.itunes:subtitle: Whoever thought finding the law could be a challenge? Not if it's on a 7 ft tall stela for all to see - now, as then, finding the law can be almost as complicated as finding justice

item.title: Eurovision/European Broadcast Union Statutes, 1950
item.itunes:subtitle: What's the most popular television show in the world that you may never have heard of? Founding documents, politics, dancing apes, and the shared cultural moments that are the Eurovision Song Contest

item.title: IRS Form 1040, 1914
item.itunes:subtitle: Line after line, year after year, the forms that keep information organized, processes processing, and civilization working

item.title: "Operation Mincemeat" Faked Documents, 1943
item.itunes:subtitle: When is a fake not a fake? A strange WWII stories, authentically fake documents on a dead fake British officer to divert German attention from an invasion of Sicily and change the course of the war-for real (researched/co-written by Kate Merifield)

item.title: Voyager "Golden Records", 1977
item.itunes:subtitle: Mixtape, love letter, time capsule, letter of introduction, message in a bottle and more, not to mention the furthest object of human construction, sending our messages out to the stars, seeking understanding and remembrance

item.title: Webster's Dictionary, 1828
item.itunes:subtitle: Words define a language, and in turn languages help to define cultures and societies. And people define words, as the last man who tried to define them all himself knew, in the process trying also to define and distinguish his developing nation

item.title: Liber Abaci (Arabic Numerals), 1202
item.itunes:subtitle: 800 years ago, an Italian mathematician and world traveler brought the gift of digits to Europe, from India, through Arabia, and taught the West how to count, and calculate, and figure it all out

item.title: Palm Beach County "Butterfly" Ballot, 2000
item.itunes:subtitle: Vote for the person you want, somebody in charge counts â€˜em up and then we find out the winner. As if. The many ways that can go wrong, and the importance of good design done well but somebody who knows how

item.title: Stock Market Crash Ticker Tape, 1929
item.itunes:subtitle: When the market started to crash, the ticker, reliable source of up-to-the-second information, fell behind, and all of a sudden not knowing what you didn't know was worse than knowing, and the spiral went down and down from there

item.title: FDR Thanksgiving Proclamation, 1939
item.itunes:subtitle: Two Thanksgivings! Twice the turkey, twice the parades, twice the football? Nope, but for a few years the nation was split by a presidential proclamation that didn't quite work as intended

item.title: Declaration of Independence Deleted Passage, 1776
item.itunes:subtitle: How do you read words that aren't there? The towering idea of the Declaration of Independence, the passage on slavery deleted before its adoption, and the hole that silence has left behind

item.title: Nupedia (Wikipedia precursor), 2000
item.itunes:subtitle: Encyclopedias have changed, due to the one you know - but actually the one you probably don't, and the ways in which we know the things we know are changing right along with them

item.title: Richter Scale, 1935
item.itunes:subtitle: The Richter Scale...isn't used any more, and the man who created it had a mind more sensitive to the movements of the earth than the subtleties of society

item.title: Fannie Farmer Cookbook, 1896
item.itunes:subtitle: Hungry yet? The cookbook, and the woman, who standardized recipes and encouraged us all to think about food as science and art

item.title: Vietnam Veterans Memorial, 1982
item.itunes:subtitle: Name after name, row after row, the wall, and the things we bring to it, including ourselves, all of which help us remember and reconcile

item.title: Statistical Significance, 1925
item.itunes:subtitle: How to know when to believe a research study, drawing the line between real and spurious, and how a "random" line in a book defines the way we understand the world

item.title: Annals of the World, 1650
item.itunes:subtitle: Bishop James Ussher, the search for the beginning of the universe, and the date (and time) of Creation, making the most of the tools at hand

item.title: Alfred Nobel's Will, 1895
item.itunes:subtitle: One of the greatest legacies, and worst-written wills of all times, though almost completely not what the author had in mind; wills, their history and how to (almost always) get the last word

item.title: "The Star-Spangled Banner", 1814
item.itunes:subtitle: O say do you know...the story behind the Star-Spangled Banner? It took off fast, then slowly, and has stood the test of time while still, and always, becoming

item.title: Philosophical Transactions, 1665
item.itunes:subtitle: The first scholarly journal, at the dawn of the Scientific Revolution, and helping to give birth to the way we write and think about scholarship and investigation...and now it's all changing again

item.title: First Woman's College Diploma, 1840
item.itunes:subtitle: It's just "a piece of paper," except it's not. The story of Catherine Elizabeth Benson Brewer, the first woman to receive a diploma, and how we recognize achievement, yesterday and today (written/researched/recorded by Kelsey Gibbons)

item.title: Joseph McCarthy's "List", 1950
item.itunes:subtitle: I have in my hand a list...of 57 Communists in the State Department. Or was it 205? Or 81? Or was there a list at all? How documents get their power, from us, even if they don't exist

item.title: The Exaltation of Inanna, c2300 BCE
item.itunes:subtitle: One of the oldest works of literature we know, a hymn written by Enheduanna, perhaps the first known named author, in the Sumerian city of Ur, a plea for help that doesn't feel out of place 4300 years later

item.title: Donation of Constantine, c750
item.itunes:subtitle: Why the Popes ruled Italy: one of the greatest gifts in history, as a result of one of the greatest forgery in history, the art of making a document lie, and figuring out what's real and what's not

item.title: Zimmerman Telegram, 1917
item.itunes:subtitle: The secret decoding of a secret message: how Britain found out that Germany wanted Mexico to attack America to keep them out of World War I, and the spectacular backfire that resulted (researched/produced by Jill Fenno)

item.title: Airplane Black Box/Flight Data Recorder, 1958
item.itunes:subtitle: The black box that reveals, not conceals: how flight recorders were developed, how they work, how they're used, what happens to the information, and how they're related to the 8-track tape

item.title: "We Can Do It!" Poster/Rosie the Riveter, 1943
item.itunes:subtitle: That poster--isn't what you think. She's not Rosie the Riveter, and the lives she's led, as, feminist icon, symbol of wartime solidarity, cultural nostalgia touchstone, are almost all entirely wrong

item.title: Alaska Purchase Check, 1868
item.itunes:subtitle: Seward's Folly, enabled by a single piece of paper exchanged for $7.2 million, adding vast new territories to the US, and telling us about how money moves, and how people feel about how that's changing (researched/produced/co-written by Andrew Kyrios)

item.title: Zapruder Film, 1963
item.itunes:subtitle: 486 frames, likely the most scrutinized film of all time, dissected, debated, debunked, and the harbinger of things to come as events are increasingly documented and shared

item.title: Rosetta Stone, 196BCE
item.itunes:subtitle: Undoubtedly one of the great document stories of all time, which help us to think about permanence, durability, and what can happen when media outlast messages

item.title: Mental Disorder Diagnosis Manual, 1952
item.itunes:subtitle: Are you crazy? Maybe yes, maybe no, but either way, this book lays out what mental disorders are, and aren't, and reinforce the power that we give names of all kinds

item.title: The Book of Mormon, 1830
item.itunes:subtitle: Joseph Smith: led to long-buried golden tablets revealing lost truths...or the most successful humbug even known? Words, faith, a backstory that defies logic, and the power of belief

item.title: Einstein's Letter to Roosevelt, 1939
item.itunes:subtitle: A two page letter from a great mind to a great leader about a great subject matter, the beginning of the Atomic Age and one of the oldest forms of writing

item.title: X-Ray, 1895
item.itunes:subtitle: A shadowy skeletal hand gives us the first good look inside ourselves, and we've not been the same since

item.title: Riot Act, 1714
item.itunes:subtitle: If you don't say it out loud, it doesn't work--magic spells, wedding ceremonies, and how to stop a riot, 18th Century style

item.title: IQ Test, 1905
item.itunes:subtitle: The origin of standardized tests, the quantification of intelligence, and measuring and numbering of us all (written/researched/produced/recorded by Eli Gander-Rood)

item.title: Space Needle "Sketch", 1959 (Live)
item.itunes:subtitle: How an icon gets conceived, how ideas get recorded, the value of cocktail napkins (real and virtual), and the story of how stories get started

item.title: Pope Benedict XVI Resignation, 2013
item.itunes:subtitle: Moving on gracefully (or not), the history of papal resignations, and why it helps to have it all written down

item.title: Rules of Association Football (Soccer), 1863
item.itunes:subtitle: What makes sports sports, why the rules matter, how football got the way it is, and the basis of creativity

item.title: "Letters of Transit", 1942
item.itunes:subtitle: You must remember this: Casablanca, passports, exit visas, fictional documents, Rick, Ilsa, Sam's piano and the words that move us

item.title: What is the Third Estate?, 1789
item.itunes:subtitle: The priest, the pamphlet, the Revolution, and lightning in a bottle, all in the right place at the right time

item.title: Robert's Rules of Order, 1876
item.itunes:subtitle: Bringing order to chaos, one meeting at a time

item.title: Protocols of the Elders of Zion, c1900
item.itunes:subtitle: Fraud, plagiarism, hate, and the power of belief no matter what

item.title: AIDS Quilt, 1987
item.itunes:subtitle: Love, loss, and the stories a quilt can tell

item.title: The 18 1/2 Minute Gap, 1972
item.itunes:subtitle: Watergate, the Nixon White House, and the benefits of unsolved mysteries

item.title: Gutenberg Indulgence, 1454
item.itunes:subtitle: What Gutenberg printed first, the unexpected effects all his works had, and how it's all about to happen again

item.title: Internet Protocol, 1981
item.itunes:subtitle: The simple genius that makes the Internet happen

item.title: The Gregorian Calendar, 1582
item.itunes:subtitle: The power of one person, the power of one document

item.title: John Snow's Cholera Map, 1853
item.itunes:subtitle: Making sense of Big Data, 19th century edition (written/researched/produced/recorded by Andrew Brink)

item.title: Mao's Little Red Book, 1964
item.itunes:subtitle: Words matter, and who says them does too

item.title: Barack Obama Birth Certificate, 1961
item.itunes:subtitle: Authenticity, authentication, and last piece of paper you might have

item.title: The 19th Amendment, 1920
item.itunes:subtitle: Where exactly is the Constitution? Chances are, what you think...is wrong
